Title: Derivative Definition (Limit Definition)
Notes: Defines the instantaneous rate of change of function f at point x. Fundamental to differential calculus, used in marginal analysis, optimization, and sensitivity calculations.

Title: Power Rule
Notes: Differentiates power functions where n is any real constant. Used extensively in utility functions, production functions, and cost curves.

Title: Product Rule
Notes: Differentiates the product of two functions. Critical for revenue (price × quantity), present value calculations, and compounded growth models.

Title: Quotient Rule
Notes: Differentiates the quotient of two functions where g(x) ≠ 0. Essential for ratios like P/E, debt-to-equity, and Sharpe ratio derivatives.

Title: Chain Rule
Notes: Differentiates composite functions. Fundamental for nested relationships in option pricing and utility of wealth models.

Title: Exponential and Logarithmic Derivatives
Notes: Natural exponential is its own derivative. Fundamental in continuous compounding, log-returns, and growth models.

Title: L'Hôpital's Rule
Notes: Evaluates indeterminate forms 0/0 or ∞/∞. Used in asymptotic analysis and limit pricing models.

Title: Fundamental Theorem of Calculus (Part I)
Notes: Links differentiation and integration as inverse operations. Essential for cumulative distributions and wealth accumulation.

Title: Fundamental Theorem of Calculus (Part II)
Notes: Evaluates definite integrals using antiderivatives. Foundation for computing present values and expected values.

Title: Integration by Parts
Notes: Integrates products of functions. Essential for option pricing expectation calculations and PDEs.

Title: Taylor Series Expansion
Notes: Approximates function near point a using derivatives. Used for delta-gamma approximations and linearization.

Title: Maclaurin Series
Notes: Taylor series centered at a = 0. Used in approximating option pricing formulas and probability distributions.

Title: Gradient Vector
Equation: \nabla f = \left(\frac{\partial f}{\partial x_1}, \frac{\partial f}{\partial x_2}, \ldots, \frac{\partial f}{\partial x_n}\right)
Notes: Vector of partial derivatives pointing in direction of steepest ascent. Used in portfolio optimization and gradient descent.

Title: Hessian Matrix
Equation: H(f) = \begin{bmatrix} \frac{\partial^2 f}{\partial x_1^2} & \cdots & \frac{\partial^2 f}{\partial x_1 \partial x_n} \\ \vdots & \ddots & \vdots \\ \frac{\partial^2 f}{\partial x_n \partial x_1} & \cdots & \frac{\partial^2 f}{\partial x_n^2} \end{bmatrix}
Notes: Symmetric matrix of second-order partial derivatives. Characterizes local curvature. Used for second-order optimization conditions.

Title: Jacobian Matrix
Equation: J = \begin{bmatrix} \frac{\partial f_1}{\partial x_1} & \cdots & \frac{\partial f_1}{\partial x_n} \\ \vdots & \ddots & \vdots \\ \frac{\partial f_m}{\partial x_1} & \cdots & \frac{\partial f_m}{\partial x_n} \end{bmatrix}
Notes: Matrix of first-order partial derivatives for vector-valued functions. Used in change of variables and sensitivity analysis.

Title: Implicit Function Theorem
Notes: Provides derivative of implicitly defined functions. Used in comparative statics and equilibrium analysis.

Title: Leibniz Integral Rule
Notes: Differentiates integrals with variable limits. Essential for dynamic optimization and envelope theorems.

Title: Lagrangian Multiplier Condition
Notes: First-order condition for constrained optimization. λ represents shadow price of constraint.

Title: Euler-Lagrange Equation
Notes: Necessary condition for extremizing functionals in calculus of variations. Used in optimal control theory.

Title: Mean Value Theorem
Notes: Guarantees existence of point where instantaneous rate equals average rate. Foundation for Taylor's theorem.

Title: Partial Derivative
Equation: \frac{\partial f}{\partial x_i} = \lim_{h \to 0} \frac{f(x_1, \ldots, x_i + h, \ldots, x_n) - f(x_1, \ldots, x_i, \ldots, x_n)}{h}
Notes: Derivative with respect to one variable holding others constant. Essential for marginal analysis in economics.

Title: Green's Theorem
Equation: \oint_C (L\,dx + M\,dy) = \iint_D \left(\frac{\partial M}{\partial x} - \frac{\partial L}{\partial y}\right) dA
Notes: Relates line integral around closed curve to double integral over enclosed region. Connects circulation to curl.

Title: Stokes' Theorem
Notes: Generalizes Green's theorem to three dimensions. Relates surface integral of curl to line integral around boundary.

Title: Divergence Theorem (Gauss's Theorem)
Notes: Relates volume integral of divergence to flux through boundary. Used in conservation laws and PDEs.

Title: Integration by Substitution
Notes: Reverse of chain rule for integration. Essential for computing expectations with transformed variables.

Title: Partial Integration (Multivariable)
Notes: Extends fundamental theorem to partial derivatives. Used in solving PDEs like Black-Scholes.

Title: Cauchy-Schwarz Inequality
Notes: Fundamental inequality for inner products. Foundation for correlation coefficient being in [-1,1].

Title: Convexity and Jensen's Inequality
Notes: For convex f, function lies above tangent lines. Used in risk aversion analysis and portfolio optimization.

Title: Envelope Theorem
Notes: Derivative of value function equals partial derivative of Lagrangian at optimum. Used in comparative statics.

Title: Intermediate Value Theorem
Equation: f(a) \leq k \leq f(b) \implies \exists c \in (a,b): f(c) = k
Notes: Continuous function attains all intermediate values. Guarantees existence of equilibria and roots.

Title: Total Derivative
Notes: Rate of change along a path. Chain rule for multivariable functions. Essential for dynamic models.

Title: Budget Constraint
Notes: Total expenditure on all goods cannot exceed income. Fundamental to consumer choice theory. p_i is price of good i (p_i > 0), x_i is quantity (x_i >= 0), m is income (m > 0). Typically binding at optimum.

Title: Utility Maximization (Lagrangian)
Equation: \mathcal{L}(x_1, \ldots, x_n, \lambda) = u(x_1, \ldots, x_n) - \lambda \left( \sum_{i=1}^{n} p_i x_i - m \right)
Notes: Lagrangian formulation for utility maximization subject to budget constraint. FOCs yield Marshallian demand functions. u(·) is utility function (continuous, differentiable, strictly quasi-concave), λ is Lagrange multiplier (marginal utility of income).

Title: Marginal Rate of Substitution
Notes: Rate at which consumer trades good y for good x maintaining constant utility. At optimum MRS equals price ratio. MU_x is marginal utility of x, assumes diminishing MRS for convex preferences.

Title: Marshallian Demand
Notes: Uncompensated demand from utility maximization. Dependent on all prices and income. Properties: homogeneous of degree zero in (p,m), satisfy budget constraint and Slutsky symmetry. Used in welfare analysis.

Title: Hicksian (Compensated) Demand
Equation: h_i(p_1, \ldots, p_n, \bar{u}) = \arg\min_{x} \sum_{j=1}^{n} p_j x_j \quad \text{s.t.} \quad u(x_1, \ldots, x_n) \geq \bar{u}
Notes: Compensated demand from expenditure minimization at fixed utility. Properties: homogeneous of degree zero in p, no income effect (pure substitution), satisfies compensated law of demand.

Title: Indirect Utility Function
Equation: v(p_1, \ldots, p_n, m) = \max_{x} u(x_1, \ldots, x_n) \quad \text{s.t.} \quad \sum_{i=1}^{n} p_i x_i = m
Notes: Maximum utility attainable given prices and income. Properties: homogeneous of degree zero in (p,m), strictly increasing in m, decreasing in p_i, quasi-convex in p. Foundation for Roy's Identity.

Title: Expenditure Function
Equation: e(p_1, \ldots, p_n, \bar{u}) = \min_{x} \sum_{i=1}^{n} p_i x_i \quad \text{s.t.} \quad u(x_1, \ldots, x_n) = \bar{u}
Notes: Minimum expenditure to achieve utility level. Properties: homogeneous of degree one in p, strictly increasing in u and p_i, concave in p. Dual to indirect utility. Foundation for Shephard's Lemma.

Title: Roy's Identity
Equation: x_i(p, m) = -\frac{\partial v(p, m) / \partial p_i}{\partial v(p, m) / \partial m}
Notes: Derives Marshallian demand from indirect utility function using envelope theorem. Assumes v(·) is differentiable and marginal utility of income is nonzero. Application of duality theory.

Title: Shephard's Lemma
Notes: Derives Hicksian demand from expenditure function using envelope theorem. Shows compensated demand equals derivative of expenditure function. Used in welfare analysis and deadweight loss calculations.

Title: Slutsky Equation
Equation: \frac{\partial x_i(p, m)}{\partial p_j} = \frac{\partial h_i(p, \bar{u})}{\partial p_j} - \frac{\partial x_i(p, m)}{\partial m} \cdot x_j(p, m)
Notes: Decomposes price effect into substitution effect (first term) and income effect (second term). Matrix form: D_p x = D_p h - D_m x · x^T where D_p h is negative semidefinite. Critical for classifying goods.

Title: Elasticity of Demand
Notes: Price elasticity: percentage change in quantity per percentage change in price. |ε| > 1 is elastic, |ε| < 1 is inelastic, |ε| = 1 is unit elastic. Income elasticity and cross-price elasticity defined analogously.

Title: Cobb-Douglas Utility Function
Notes: Homothetic preferences with constant expenditure shares. Marshallian demand: x_i* = α_i m/p_i. Elasticity of substitution σ=1. Income elasticity equals 1. Widely used in macro and CGE models.

Title: CES Utility Function
Notes: Constant Elasticity of Substitution utility. Elasticity: σ=1/(1-ρ). Special cases: ρ→0 yields Cobb-Douglas, ρ=1 yields perfect substitutes, ρ→-∞ yields Leontief. Used in international trade and growth theory.

Title: Cobb-Douglas Production Function
Notes: Production function with capital K and labor L. A is total factor productivity, α and β are output elasticities. Returns to scale: α+β<1 (DRS), =1 (CRS), >1 (IRS). Elasticity of substitution σ=1.

Title: CES Production Function
Notes: Constant Elasticity of Substitution production. Elasticity: σ=1/(1-ρ). Special cases: ρ→0 yields Cobb-Douglas, ρ=1 yields linear, ρ→-∞ yields Leontief. Assumes constant returns to scale.

Title: Returns to Scale
Notes: Measures how output scales with proportional input increases. t>1 is scaling factor, γ is degree of homogeneity. CRS implies perfect replication and Euler's theorem. Critical for competitive equilibrium existence.

Title: Marginal Rate of Technical Substitution
Notes: Rate at which capital substitutes for labor maintaining constant output. At cost minimum MRTS equals input price ratio w/r. MP_L and MP_K are marginal products. Assumes diminishing MRTS (convex isoquants).

Title: Cost Minimization (Lagrangian)
Notes: Lagrangian for cost minimization subject to production constraint. FOCs yield conditional factor demands K^c(w,r,Y) and L^c(w,r,Y). λ is marginal cost. w is wage, r is capital rental rate.

Title: Profit Maximization Condition
Equation: \max_{K, L} \pi = p \cdot f(K, L) - wL - rK \implies p \cdot \frac{\partial f}{\partial L} = w, \; p \cdot \frac{\partial f}{\partial K} = r
Notes: Competitive firm sets marginal revenue product equal to factor price. p is output price (exogenous), π is profit. Under CRS, FOCs determine factor demands but not output scale. Yields unconditional factor demands.

Title: Hotelling's Lemma
Equation: y^*(p, w) = \frac{\partial \pi(p, w)}{\partial p} \quad \text{and} \quad x_i^*(p, w) = -\frac{\partial \pi(p, w)}{\partial w_i}
Notes: Derives supply and factor demands from profit function using envelope theorem. π(p,w) is profit function, y* is output supply, x_i* is demand for input i. Profit function is convex in p, concave in w.

Title: Envelope Theorem
Notes: Derivative of value function equals partial derivative of objective at optimum. Indirect effect through dx*/dα vanishes by FOC. Foundation for Roy's Identity, Shephard's Lemma, Hotelling's Lemma.

Title: Monopoly Pricing (MR=MC)
Notes:
Monopolist sets MR=MC. p(Q) is inverse demand, ε is price elasticity. MR

1 for positive output. Creates deadweight loss.

Title: Lerner Index
Notes: Measures market power as percentage markup of price over marginal cost. L∈[0,1] where L=0 for perfect competition. Under Cournot with n symmetric firms: L=s/|ε| where s=1/n is market share.

Title: Nash Equilibrium Condition
Equation: s_i^* \in \arg\max_{s_i \in S_i} u_i(s_i, s_{-i}^*) \quad \forall i \in N
Notes: Strategy profile where no player can unilaterally improve by deviating. s_i is player i's strategy, S_i is strategy space, u_i is payoff function. Existence guaranteed by Nash's theorem. Foundation of non-cooperative game theory.

Title: Cournot Equilibrium
Equation: q_i^* = \arg\max_{q_i} \left[ p\left(\sum_{j=1}^{n} q_j\right) q_i - C_i(q_i) \right] \implies p'(Q^*) q_i^* + p(Q^*) = C_i'(q_i^*)
Notes: Oligopoly with simultaneous quantity choices. q_i is firm i's output, Q is total output, p(Q) is inverse demand. As n→∞, converges to perfect competition. More competitive than monopoly, less than Bertrand.

Title: Bertrand Equilibrium
Notes: Oligopoly with simultaneous price choices. D_i is demand for firm i. With homogeneous products and n≥2: p_i*=c (Bertrand paradox). With differentiated products: p_i*>c. More competitive than Cournot with homogeneous products.

Title: Stackelberg Leader Output
Equation: q_L^* = \arg\max_{q_L} \left[ p(q_L + R(q_L)) q_L - C_L(q_L) \right] \quad \text{where} \quad R(q_L) = \arg\max_{q_F} \left[ p(q_L + q_F) q_F - C_F(q_F) \right]
Notes: Sequential quantity competition where leader moves first. R(q_L) is follower's reaction function. Leader incorporates dR/dq_L<0 (strategic substitutes). Leader produces more and earns higher profit than in Cournot. First-mover advantage.

Title: Consumer Surplus
Equation: CS = \int_0^{Q^*} p(q) \, dq - p^* Q^* = \int_{p^*}^{\infty} D(p) \, dp
Notes: Area between demand curve and market price, representing consumer welfare gain. p(q) is inverse demand (willingness to pay), D(p) is demand function. With linear demand p=a-bQ: CS=½(a-p*)Q*.

Title: Producer Surplus
Equation: PS = p^* Q^* - \int_0^{Q^*} MC(q) \, dq = \int_0^{p^*} S(p) \, dp
Notes: Area between market price and supply curve, representing producer welfare gain. MC(q) is marginal cost, S(p) is supply function. Equals variable profit. In long-run competitive equilibrium with free entry: PS=0.

Title: Welfare Loss (Deadweight Loss)
Notes: Loss of total surplus due to market distortions (taxes, monopoly, price controls). Q^c, p^c are competitive equilibrium; Q*, p* are distorted. Second expression is Harberger's triangle for small distortions. DWL increases with square of tax rate.

Title: Dividend Discount Model (General)
Notes: Intrinsic stock value equals present value of all expected future dividends. V_0=current stock value; D_t=expected dividend at time t; r=required return on equity. Foundational framework for equity valuation.

Title: Gordon Growth Model (Constant Growth DDM)
Notes: Values stock assuming constant perpetual dividend growth. V_0=current value; D_1=next dividend; r=required return; g=growth rate. Critical assumption: r>g. Widely used for mature companies.

Title: Two-Stage Dividend Discount Model
Notes: Accommodates high-growth phase followed by stable growth. g_1=initial growth rate; g_2=perpetual rate after period n. Used for firms transitioning from growth to maturity.

Title: H-Model
Notes: Dividend growth declines linearly from g_S to g_L over 2H periods. H=half-life of high-growth period. Closed-form solution for gradual growth transitions.

Title: Free Cash Flow to Firm (FCFF)
Notes: Cash available to all investors after operating expenses, taxes, and reinvestment. EBIT=earnings before interest and taxes; T=tax rate; Dep=depreciation; CapEx=capital expenditures; ΔNWC=change in net working capital. Independent of capital structure.

Title: Free Cash Flow to Equity (FCFE)
Notes: Cash available to equity holders after all expenses, reinvestment, and debt obligations. NI=net income; Net Borrowing=new debt issued minus repayments. Used for direct equity valuation.

Title: Enterprise Value
Notes: Total firm value to all investors, net of cash. Market Cap=share price × shares outstanding; Total Debt=market value of debt; Cash=cash equivalents. Used in M&A and valuation multiples.

Title: Equity Value from Enterprise Value
Notes: Derives equity value from enterprise value by removing debt claims and adding cash. Reconciles FCFF-based valuations to equity value. Represents residual claim after debt holders satisfied.

Title: Weighted Average Cost of Capital (WACC)
Notes: Average rate to finance assets, weighted by capital structure. E=equity value; D=debt value; V=E+D; r_E=cost of equity; r_D=cost of debt; T=tax rate. Discount rate for FCFF in DCF valuation.

Title: Cost of Equity (CAPM)
Notes: CAPM estimates cost of equity as risk-free rate plus systematic risk premium. r_f=risk-free rate; β_E=equity beta; r_m=expected market return; (r_m-r_f)=market risk premium. Widely used in valuation.

Title: Cost of Debt (After-Tax)
Notes: After-tax cost accounts for tax deductibility of interest. r_D=pre-tax cost of debt; T=corporate tax rate. Tax shield T·r_D represents savings per dollar of interest. Used in WACC calculations.

Title: Unlevered Beta
Notes: Asset beta measures systematic risk without financial leverage. β_U=unlevered beta; β_L=levered beta; D=debt; E=equity; T=tax rate. Used to compare business risk across different capital structures.

Title: Levered Beta (Hamada Equation)
Notes: Relates levered beta to unlevered beta, adjusting for financial leverage. Financial leverage amplifies systematic risk. Assumes debt is risk-free (β_D=0). Used to re-lever beta for target capital structures.

Title: Modigliani-Miller Proposition I (No Taxes)
Notes: In perfect markets, levered firm value equals unlevered firm value; capital structure is irrelevant. V_L=levered firm value; V_U=unlevered firm value. Foundational result showing financing decisions don't affect firm value.

Title: Modigliani-Miller Proposition II (No Taxes)
Notes: Cost of equity increases linearly with debt-to-equity ratio, reflecting financial risk. r_A=cost of assets (unlevered WACC); r_D=cost of debt. Benefit of cheaper debt offset by higher equity costs.

Title: Modigliani-Miller with Corporate Taxes
Notes: Levered firm value exceeds unlevered by present value of tax shield. T·D is perpetual tax shield assuming constant debt. Implies tax advantage to debt financing (assumes no bankruptcy costs).

Title: Adjusted Present Value (APV)
Notes: Values levered firm by adding/subtracting financing side effects to unlevered value. More flexible than WACC for changing capital structures. Used in leveraged buyouts and complex financing scenarios.

Title: Residual Income Model
Notes: Equity value equals book value plus PV of residual income (earnings above required return). RI_t=NI_t - r·B_{t-1}. Assumes clean surplus accounting. Useful when dividends unpredictable but earnings stable.

Title: Economic Value Added (EVA)
Notes: Dollar surplus value created above cost of capital. NOPAT=net operating profit after taxes; Capital=invested capital. EVA>0 indicates value creation. Performance metric for value-based management.

Title: Price-to-Earnings Ratio (P/E)
Notes: Valuation multiple comparing price to earnings per share. P_0=current price; E_1=expected EPS. Trailing P/E uses historical EPS; forward P/E uses forecasted EPS. Widely used for relative valuation.

Title: PEG Ratio
Notes: Adjusts P/E for earnings growth. g=expected annual growth rate (%). PEG near 1 often considered fair value. Used in growth stock analysis. Doesn't account for risk or capital intensity differences.

Title: Price-to-Book Ratio (P/B)
Notes: Compares market value to book value. B_0=book value per share. P/B<1 may signal undervaluation or distress; P/B>1 suggests intangible value. More relevant for asset-heavy industries like banks and manufacturing.

Title: Price-to-Sales Ratio (P/S)
Notes: Compares market cap to revenue. S_1=sales per share. Useful for firms with negative or volatile earnings. Less susceptible to accounting manipulation. Doesn't account for profitability or cost structure.

Title: EV/EBITDA Multiple
Notes: Compares enterprise value to operating earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation, amortization. Capital-structure-neutral comparison. Widely used in M&A. Preferred over P/E for leveraged firms.

Title: Justified P/E from Gordon Growth Model
Notes: Links P/E to fundamentals: payout ratio, required return, and growth. b=retention ratio; (1-b)=payout ratio; g=dividend growth rate. Used to assess whether current P/E justified by fundamentals.

Title: Sustainable Growth Rate
Notes: Maximum growth rate using internally generated funds without changing capital structure. b=retention ratio; ROE=return on equity. Assumes constant ROE and payout ratio. Growth above g requires external financing.

Title: DuPont Analysis (ROE Decomposition)
Notes: Decomposes ROE into profit margin, asset turnover, and leverage. Used to diagnose profitability drivers and identify weaknesses. Extended versions include tax burden and interest burden.

Title: Return on Invested Capital (ROIC)
Notes: Measures efficiency and profitability independent of financing. NOPAT=EBIT(1-T); Invested Capital=total assets minus non-interest-bearing current liabilities. ROIC>WACC indicates value creation. Unaffected by capital structure.

Title: Terminal Value (Gordon Growth)
Notes: Estimates PV at time n of cash flows beyond forecast period, assuming perpetual growth. FCF_{n+1}=free cash flow in first year beyond forecast; r=discount rate; g=perpetual growth rate (g<r). Used in DCF valuations.

Title: Terminal Value (Exit Multiple)
Notes: Estimates value at period n by applying valuation multiple to financial metric. Multiple=valuation multiple (e.g., EV/EBITDA, P/E); Metric_n=financial metric at time n. Used in DCF and LBO models. More practical for cyclical firms.

Title: Kolmogorov Axiom 1: Non-Negativity
Notes: The probability of any event is non-negative. First axiom of probability theory established by Kolmogorov (1933). Variables: A = event in the sample space, F = sigma-algebra of measurable events.

Title: Kolmogorov Axiom 2: Unitarity
Notes: The probability of the entire sample space equals one. Ω denotes the sample space containing all possible outcomes. This axiom normalizes the probability measure.

Title: Kolmogorov Axiom 3: Countable Additivity
Equation: P\left(\bigcup_{i=1}^{\infty} A_i\right) = \sum_{i=1}^{\infty} P(A_i) \quad \text{for pairwise disjoint } A_i
Notes: For countably many mutually exclusive events, the probability of their union equals the sum of their individual probabilities.

Title: Conditional Probability
Notes: The probability of event A given that event B has occurred. Foundation for Bayesian inference and information updating in financial markets.

Title: Bayes' Theorem
Notes: Relates conditional probabilities of events A and B. P(A) is prior probability, P(B|A) is likelihood, P(A|B) is posterior probability. Central to Bayesian econometrics.

Title: Law of Total Probability
Notes: Computes the marginal probability of event B by conditioning on a partition {A_i} of the sample space. Used in scenario analysis and risk aggregation.

Title: Independence of Events
Notes: Events A and B are independent if their joint probability equals the product of their marginal probabilities. Critical assumption in portfolio theory.

Title: Probability Mass Function (PMF)
Notes: Describes the probability distribution of a discrete random variable X. Probabilities sum to one with each p_X(x) ≥ 0.

Title: Probability Density Function (PDF)
Notes: Characterizes the distribution of a continuous random variable X. Fundamental to continuous-time finance and stochastic calculus.

Title: Cumulative Distribution Function (CDF)
Notes: The probability that random variable X takes a value less than or equal to x. Used in VaR computation and quantile-based analysis.

Title: Expected Value (Discrete)
Notes: The expectation or mean of discrete random variable X with PMF p_X(x). Central to utility theory, asset pricing, and decision theory.

Title: Expected Value (Continuous)
Notes: The expectation of continuous random variable X with PDF f_X(x). Used in risk-neutral pricing and expected utility maximization.

Title: Law of the Unconscious Statistician (LOTUS)
Notes: Computes expected value of a function g(X) without deriving the distribution of the transformed variable. Essential for computing option payoffs.

Title: Variance
Notes: Measures the dispersion of random variable X around its mean. Fundamental to portfolio theory and risk measurement.

Title: Covariance
Equation: \text{Cov}(X, Y) = E[(X - E[X])(Y - E[Y])] = E[XY] - E[X]E[Y]
Notes: Measures the joint variability of random variables X and Y. Central to portfolio diversification and factor models.

Title: Correlation Coefficient
Notes: Normalized covariance of X and Y. Always satisfies -1 ≤ ρ ≤ 1. Critical for portfolio construction and correlation trading strategies.

Title: Moment Generating Function (MGF)
Notes: Generates all moments of random variable X when it exists. The n-th moment is E[X^n] = M_X^{(n)}(0). Uniquely determines the distribution.

Title: Characteristic Function
Notes: The Fourier transform of the PDF. Always exists and uniquely determines the distribution. Essential for option pricing via Fourier methods.

Title: Normal (Gaussian) Distribution PDF
Notes: The probability density of normal random variable X ~ N(μ, σ²). Foundational in Black-Scholes, linear regression, and CAPM.

Title: Standard Normal CDF
Notes: The cumulative distribution function of standard normal variable Z ~ N(0,1). Extensively used in Black-Scholes formula and VaR calculations.

Title: Log-Normal Distribution PDF
Notes: Random variable X is log-normally distributed if ln X ~ N(μ, σ²). Models asset prices in Black-Scholes framework, ensuring prices remain positive.

Title: Poisson Distribution PMF
Notes: Models the number of events occurring in a fixed interval at constant rate λ. Used for defaults, jumps in jump-diffusion models.

Title: Exponential Distribution PDF
Notes: Models time until an event occurs under constant hazard rate λ. Exhibits memoryless property. Used in survival analysis and default time modeling.

Title: Binomial Distribution PMF
Notes: Models the number of successes in n independent Bernoulli trials. Used in binomial tree option pricing and credit portfolio modeling.

Title: Law of Large Numbers
Notes: For i.i.d. random variables with mean μ, the sample mean converges in probability to μ. Underpins Monte Carlo methods.

Title: Central Limit Theorem
Notes: Standardized sample mean converges in distribution to standard normal. Justifies normal approximations in statistical inference.

Title: Chebyshev's Inequality
Notes: Bounds the probability that random variable X deviates from its mean by k standard deviations. Used in risk management.

Title: Markov's Inequality
Notes: For non-negative random variable X ≥ 0, bounds the tail probability. Used in theoretical analysis and concentration inequalities.

Title: Jensen's Inequality
Notes: For convex function g, expectation of transformed variable is at least function applied to expectation. Critical in utility theory and option pricing.

Title: Conditional Expectation (Law of Iterated Expectations)
Notes: The expectation of the conditional expectation equals the unconditional expectation. Fundamental in martingale theory and derivatives pricing.

Title: Variance Decomposition Formula
Notes: Total variance equals expected conditional variance plus variance of conditional mean. Used in factor model risk attribution.

Title: Skewness
Notes: Measures asymmetry of the distribution. > 0 for right-skewed, < 0 for left-skewed. Important for capturing asymmetric risk.

Title: Kurtosis
Notes: Measures tail heaviness. Normal distribution has kurtosis = 3. > 3 is leptokurtic (heavy tails). Critical for VaR modeling.

Title: Covariance Matrix
Notes: For random vector X, the covariance matrix Σ is symmetric positive semi-definite. Fundamental in portfolio optimization and PCA.

Title: Sample Mean
Notes: The arithmetic average of observed values. Unbiased estimator of population mean and minimizes sum of squared deviations.

Title: Sample Variance
Notes: Measures dispersion using Bessel's correction (n-1 denominator) to provide unbiased estimate of population variance.

Title: Standard Error of the Mean
Notes: Quantifies the precision of the sample mean as an estimator of the population mean. Critical for confidence intervals.

Title: OLS Estimator (Matrix Form)
Notes: The OLS estimator provides BLUE under Gauss-Markov assumptions. Minimizes sum of squared residuals.

Title: OLS Normal Equations
Notes: First-order conditions for minimizing sum of squared residuals. Solution exists when X has full column rank.

Title: Gauss-Markov Conditions
Notes: These conditions ensure OLS is BLUE: conditional mean independence (exogeneity) and homoskedasticity with no serial correlation.

Title: R-squared
Notes: Measures proportion of variance in dependent variable explained by model. Ranges from 0 to 1.

Title: Adjusted R-squared
Notes: Penalizes model complexity to prevent overfitting. Preferred for model comparison with different numbers of regressors.

Title: F-statistic
Notes: Tests joint null hypothesis that all slope coefficients are zero. Under null, F ~ F_{k-1, n-k}.

Title: t-statistic
Notes: Tests hypotheses about individual regression coefficients. Under null and normality, t_j ~ t_{n-k}.

Title: Maximum Likelihood Estimator
Notes: The MLE selects parameters that maximize likelihood of observed data. Asymptotically efficient and normally distributed.

Title: Fisher Information
Notes: Quantifies information a random variable carries about an unknown parameter. Higher information implies more precise estimation.

Title: Cramér-Rao Lower Bound
Notes: The CRLB provides minimum possible variance for any unbiased estimator. MLE achieves this bound asymptotically.

Title: Likelihood Ratio Test
Notes: Compares nested models by testing parameter restrictions. Under null, LR ~ χ²_r where r is number of restrictions.

Title: Wald Test
Notes: Evaluates parameter restrictions using unrestricted estimates. Under null, W ~ χ²_r asymptotically.

Title: AIC (Akaike Information Criterion)
Notes: Balances model fit and complexity. Lower AIC indicates better model. Based on Kullback-Leibler divergence.

Title: BIC (Bayesian Information Criterion)
Notes: Imposes stronger penalty for complexity than AIC. Consistent for model selection as n → ∞.

Title: Heteroskedasticity-Consistent Standard Errors (White)
Notes: White's robust covariance estimator provides valid inference under heteroskedasticity of unknown form.

Title: Newey-West HAC Estimator
Notes: Provides heteroskedasticity and autocorrelation consistent (HAC) standard errors. Uses Bartlett kernel weights.

Title: Two-Stage Least Squares (2SLS) Estimator
Notes: 2SLS provides consistent estimation when regressors are endogenous. P_Z = Z(Z^T Z)^{-1}Z^T is projection matrix.

Title: Generalized Method of Moments (GMM) Estimator
Notes: Generalizes IV estimation using moment conditions E[g(x, θ_0)] = 0. Optimal weighting matrix W is inverse of moment covariance.

Title: Panel Data Fixed Effects Estimator
Notes: The within transformation eliminates time-invariant individual effects by demeaning. Controls for all time-invariant unobserved heterogeneity.

Title: Hausman Test
Notes: Tests whether individual effects are correlated with regressors. Large H rejects RE in favor of FE.

Title: Durbin-Watson Statistic
Notes: Tests for first-order serial correlation in regression residuals. Values near 2 indicate no autocorrelation.

Title: Breusch-Pagan Test
Notes: Tests for heteroskedasticity by regressing squared residuals on regressors. Under null of homoskedasticity, BP ~ χ²_{k-1}.

Title: Granger Causality
Notes: Tests whether past values of x help predict y beyond past values of y alone. Causality refers to predictive power, not true causation.

Title: Engle-Granger Cointegration
Notes: Tests whether non-stationary series share a common stochastic trend. Test residuals for unit root using augmented Dickey-Fuller test.

Title: GARCH(1,1) Model
Notes: Captures volatility clustering. Conditional variance depends on past squared shocks and past variance. Requires α + β < 1 for stationarity.

Title: Vector Autoregression (VAR)
Notes: Models multiple time series jointly. Each variable depends on its own lags and lags of all other variables. Used for forecasting and impulse response analysis.

Title: Matrix Multiplication
Notes: Defines the product of two matrices. For A ∈ ℝ^{m×n} and B ∈ ℝ^{n×p}, product AB ∈ ℝ^{m×p}. Non-commutative: AB ≠ BA in general.

Title: Matrix Transpose Properties
Notes: The transpose of a product equals the product of transposes in reverse order. Fundamental in deriving covariance matrices and OLS normal equations.

Title: Matrix Inverse
Notes: A square matrix A is invertible if A^{-1} exists. Exists iff det(A) ≠ 0. Properties: (AB)^{-1} = B^{-1}A^{-1}.

Title: Determinant (Leibniz Formula)
Notes: Sum over all permutations in symmetric group S_n. Properties: det(AB) = det(A)det(B), det(A^T) = det(A).

Title: Cramer's Rule
Notes: Solves linear system Ax = b. A_i is formed by replacing i-th column of A with vector b. Valid when det(A) ≠ 0.

Title: Eigenvalue Equation
Notes: Defines eigenvalue λ and eigenvector v for matrix A. Essential for PCA, dynamic systems stability, and Markov chain convergence.

Title: Characteristic Polynomial
Notes: Roots are eigenvalues of A. Sum of eigenvalues equals tr(A), product equals det(A). Used in spectral analysis.

Title: Spectral Decomposition
Notes: For symmetric A, Q is orthogonal with eigenvectors as columns, Λ = diag(λ_1, ..., λ_n). All eigenvalues real. Fundamental for PCA.

Title: Singular Value Decomposition (SVD)
Notes: For any matrix A, U and V are orthogonal, Σ is diagonal with singular values. Used in dimensionality reduction and matrix approximation.

Title: Cholesky Decomposition
Notes: For positive definite A, unique lower triangular L with positive diagonal exists. Used in simulating correlated random variables.

Title: QR Decomposition
Notes: Q has orthonormal columns, R is upper triangular. Used in solving least squares problems. More stable than normal equations.

Title: LU Decomposition
Notes: L is lower triangular with unit diagonal, U is upper triangular. Efficient for solving multiple linear systems with same coefficient matrix.

Title: Trace Properties
Notes: Trace is sum of diagonal elements. Cyclic property: tr(ABC) = tr(CAB) = tr(BCA). Also: tr(A) = Σλ_i.

Title: Rank-Nullity Theorem
Notes: Rank plus nullity equals number of columns. Fundamental for determining solution existence and uniqueness.

Title: Positive Definite Matrix Conditions
Notes: For symmetric A and all non-zero x. Equivalent: all eigenvalues > 0, all leading principal minors positive. Essential for covariance matrices.

Title: Sherman-Morrison Formula
Notes: Updates inverse after rank-one modification. Reduces complexity from O(n³) to O(n²). Used in recursive least squares.

Title: Woodbury Matrix Identity
Notes: Generalizes Sherman-Morrison to rank-k updates. Essential for Kalman filter updates and portfolio optimization.

Title: Matrix Differentiation (Gradient of Quadratic Form)
Notes: For x ∈ ℝ^n and A ∈ ℝ^{n×n}. If A is symmetric, simplifies to 2Ax. Used in portfolio optimization.

Title: Kronecker Product Properties
Notes: Properties: (A ⊗ B)^T = A^T ⊗ B^T, (A ⊗ B)^{-1} = A^{-1} ⊗ B^{-1}. Used in vectorization: vec(AXB) = (B^T ⊗ A)vec(X).

Title: Moore-Penrose Pseudoinverse
Notes: For A with full column rank. Gives least squares solution: x = A^+b minimizes ||Ax - b||₂.

Title: Projection Matrix
Notes: Projects vectors onto column space of A. Properties: P is symmetric, idempotent (P² = P). In OLS: ŷ = Py.

Title: Orthogonal Projection
Notes: Projects vector u onto vector v. Orthogonal component is u - proj_v(u). Used in Gram-Schmidt orthogonalization.

Title: Gram-Schmidt Process
Notes: Orthogonalizes linearly independent vectors. Initialize v_1 = a_1. Normalize for orthonormal basis. Basis for QR decomposition.

Title: Frobenius Norm
Notes: Euclidean norm of vectorized matrix. Properties: ||A||_F² = Σσ_i² where σ_i are singular values. Used in matrix approximation.

Title: Condition Number
Notes: Measures sensitivity of solution in Ax = b to perturbations. Large κ(A) indicates ill-conditioning. Used to assess numerical stability.

Title: Schur Complement
Notes: For block matrix M = [A B; C D] where A invertible. det(M) = det(A)det(M/A). Essential for conditional distributions in multivariate normal.

Title: National Income Identity (GDP)
Notes: Fundamental national income accounting identity for open economy. Total output equals consumption, investment, government spending, and net exports.

Title: Consumption Function (Keynesian)
Notes: Keynesian consumption relating consumption to disposable income. C_0 = autonomous consumption, c = marginal propensity to consume (0 < c < 1).

Title: Investment-Savings Identity
Notes: Equilibrium condition that national savings equals investment in closed economy. In open economy: S = I + NX.

Title: IS Curve
Notes: Goods market equilibrium showing negative relationship between output and interest rate. The coefficient 1/(1-c(1-t)) is Keynesian multiplier.

Title: Phillips Curve (Expectations-Augmented)
Notes: Inflation depends on expected inflation, unemployment gap, and supply shocks. No long-run tradeoff at u = u*.

Title: Okun's Law
Notes: Empirical relationship between output growth and unemployment changes. Okun's coefficient β typically around 2-3.

Title: Quantity Theory of Money
Notes: Equation of exchange, foundation of monetarism. With constant velocity V, money supply changes cause proportional nominal GDP changes.

Title: Fisher Equation
Notes: Relates nominal interest rate to real rate and expected inflation. Fisher effect: nominal rate adjusts one-for-one with expected inflation.

Title: Taylor Rule
Notes: Monetary policy rule for central bank interest rate setting. Original coefficients: α = β = 0.5. r* ≈ 2%.

Title: Solow Growth Model (Fundamental Equation)
Notes: Capital per worker grows when investment sf(k) exceeds depreciation δk. Converges to steady state where dk/dt = 0.

Title: Solow Steady State
Notes: Steady-state condition with population growth. Investment per worker equals break-even investment. At k*, capital and output per worker are constant.

Title: Golden Rule of Capital Accumulation
Notes: Optimal steady-state capital stock that maximizes consumption per capita. Marginal product of capital equals effective depreciation rate.

Title: Ramsey-Cass-Koopmans Euler Equation
Notes: Consumption grows when return on capital exceeds discount rate. Foundation of DSGE models. θ = relative risk aversion, ρ = time preference.

Title: Bellman Equation (Dynamic Programming)
Notes: Value function satisfies recursive relationship. Envelope theorem yields Euler equation. Foundation of computational macro.

Title: New Keynesian Phillips Curve
Notes: NKPC derived from Calvo pricing. Current inflation depends on expected future inflation and output gap. Core of NK DSGE models.

Title: Uncovered Interest Parity (UIP)
Notes: Interest rate differential equals expected depreciation. No arbitrage for international bonds without hedging.

Title: Covered Interest Parity (CIP)
Notes: Interest rate differential equals forward premium/discount. Holds almost exactly in practice. Defines arbitrage-free forward rate.

Title: Purchasing Power Parity (PPP)
Notes: Absolute PPP: exchange rate equals ratio of price levels. Long-run anchor but fails short-run. Relative PPP: Δs = π - π*.

Title: Permanent Income Hypothesis
Notes: Friedman's PIH: consumption equals annuity value of total wealth. Consumption smoothing over lifetime.

Title: DSGE Household Euler Equation
Notes: Marginal utility today equals expected discounted marginal utility tomorrow adjusted for real return. Π = gross inflation.

Title: Aggregate Demand (New Keynesian IS)
Notes: Dynamic IS curve. Output gap depends negatively on real interest rate gap. Core of three-equation NK model.

Title: Solow Residual (TFP Measurement)
Notes: Measures total factor productivity as part of output growth not explained by input growth. Used in growth accounting.

Title: Present Value
Notes: Fundamental time value of money formula. Present value of future cash flow discounted at rate r.

Title: Net Present Value
Notes: Sum of discounted cash flows. Investment decision rule: accept if NPV > 0.

Title: Internal Rate of Return
Notes: Discount rate that makes NPV equal to zero. Decision rule: accept if IRR > required return.

Title: Continuous Compounding
Notes: Limit of compound interest as compounding frequency approaches infinity. Used in derivatives pricing.

Title: Bond Pricing
Notes: Present value of coupon payments plus face value. Inverse relationship between price and yield.

Title: Duration (Macaulay)
Notes: Weighted average time to receive cash flows. Measures interest rate sensitivity. First-order approximation to price change.

Title: Modified Duration
Notes: Sensitivity of bond price to parallel yield shift. Approximation: ΔP/P ≈ -D_Mod · Δy.

Title: Convexity
Notes: Second-order sensitivity of bond price to yield changes. Improved approximation: ΔP/P ≈ -D_Mod · Δy + (1/2) · C · (Δy)².

Title: Stochastic Discount Factor
Notes: Fundamental asset pricing equation. Price equals expected discounted payoff under physical measure. M is unique SDF under complete markets.

Title: Risk-Neutral Pricing
Notes: Derivative value as discounted expected payoff under risk-neutral measure. All assets earn risk-free rate under Q.

Title: Mean-Variance Portfolio Optimization
Notes: Markowitz portfolio selection. Minimize variance for target expected return. Foundation of modern portfolio theory.

Title: Minimum Variance Portfolio
Notes: Portfolio with lowest possible variance. Unique solution at base of efficient frontier. Does not depend on expected returns.

Title: Market Portfolio Weights
Notes: Tangency portfolio weights in presence of risk-free asset. Maximizes Sharpe ratio. In CAPM equilibrium, this is market portfolio.

Title: CAPM (Capital Asset Pricing Model)
Notes: Equilibrium relation between expected return and systematic risk. Beta measures sensitivity to market portfolio.

Title: Security Market Line
Notes: CAPM in excess return form. Linear relationship between beta and expected excess return.

Title: Fama-French Three-Factor Model
Notes: Extended CAPM with size and value factors. SMB = Small Minus Big, HML = High Minus Low.

Title: Arbitrage Pricing Theory (APT)
Notes: Multifactor model with K systematic risk factors. Expected return linear in factor betas.

Title: Sharpe Ratio
Notes: Excess return per unit of total risk. Measures risk-adjusted performance. Maximized by tangency portfolio.

Title: Treynor Ratio
Notes: Excess return per unit of systematic risk. Appropriate for well-diversified portfolios.

Title: Jensen's Alpha
Notes: Excess return above CAPM prediction. Positive alpha indicates outperformance.

Title: Information Ratio
Notes: Active return per unit of active risk (tracking error). Measures manager skill relative to benchmark.

Title: Hansen-Jagannathan Bound
Notes: Lower bound on SDF volatility from observed asset returns. Any valid SDF must satisfy this inequality.

Title: Newton-Raphson Method
Notes: Iterative root-finding algorithm. Quadratic convergence near simple roots. Used in implied volatility calculation.

Title: Bisection Method
Notes: Robust root-finding via interval bisection. Guarantees convergence if f continuous and f(a_0)f(b_0) < 0. Linear convergence.

Title: Numerical Integration (Simpson's Rule)
Equation: \int_a^b f(x) dx \approx \frac{h}{3} \left[ f(x_0) + 4\sum_{i=1,3,5,...}^{n-1} f(x_i) + 2\sum_{i=2,4,6,...}^{n-2} f(x_i) + f(x_n) \right]
Notes: Quadratic interpolation for higher accuracy. Error O(h⁴). Requires even n. h = (b-a)/n. Preferred for option pricing.

Title: Monte Carlo Integration
Notes: Estimates integral by averaging at random points. Convergence O(N^{-1/2}) regardless of dimension. Effective for high-dimensional derivative pricing.

Title: Importance Sampling
Notes: Variance reduction via proposal distribution q. w_i = p(x_i)/q(x_i) are importance weights. Used in rare event simulation.

Title: Kalman Filter (Prediction)
Equation: \hat{x}_{t|t-1} = F_t \hat{x}_{t-1|t-1} + B_t u_t, \quad P_{t|t-1} = F_t P_{t-1|t-1} F_t^T + Q_t
Notes: Predicts state and covariance using transition model. Optimal for linear Gaussian systems. Used in macro forecasting.

Title: Kalman Filter (Update)
Notes: Kalman gain determines how much to trust observation vs prediction. Minimizes MSE for linear Gaussian systems.

Title: Principal Component Analysis
Notes: Finds orthogonal directions of maximum variance. Solution: eigenvectors of covariance matrix Σ. Used in factor construction.

Title: Gradient Descent Update
Notes: Iterative update in steepest descent direction. Converges to local minimum for convex L with appropriate learning rate α.

Title: Stochastic Gradient Descent
Notes: Updates using single sample gradient. Enables online learning. Requires decaying learning rate for convergence.

Title: Backpropagation (Chain Rule)
Equation: \frac{\partial L}{\partial W^{(l)}} = \frac{\partial L}{\partial a^{(l+1)}} \frac{\partial a^{(l+1)}}{\partial z^{(l+1)}} \frac{\partial z^{(l+1)}}{\partial W^{(l)}}
Notes: Computes gradients efficiently via backward error propagation. Enables deep network training. Foundation for neural networks.

Title: Logistic Regression (Sigmoid)
Equation: P(Y=1|x) = \sigma(w^T x + b) = \frac{1}{1 + e^{-(w^T x + b)}}
Notes: Models binary outcome probability via sigmoid. Convex log-likelihood enables global optimization. Used in default prediction.

Title: Softmax Function
Notes: Generalizes logistic to multi-class. Outputs probability distribution over K classes. Used in credit rating classification.

Title: Cross-Entropy Loss
Notes: Measures dissimilarity between true and predicted distributions. Equivalent to negative log-likelihood. Penalizes confident wrong predictions.

Title: Ridge Regression (L2 Regularization)
Notes: Quadratic penalty prevents overfitting. Closed-form solution always exists. Shrinks coefficients toward zero but never to exact zero.

Title: Lasso Regression (L1 Regularization)
Notes: L1 penalty induces sparsity. Performs simultaneous estimation and variable selection. Used in factor selection.

Title: Elastic Net
Notes: Combines L1 and L2 penalties. Encourages grouping effect for correlated variables. α ∈ [0,1] balances L1/L2.

Title: MCMC Metropolis-Hastings Acceptance
Notes: Generates posterior samples via accept/reject. Detailed balance ensures correct stationary distribution. Used in Bayesian inference.

Title: Gibbs Sampling
Notes: Special MCMC sampling each variable from full conditional. Acceptance always 1. Used in hierarchical models.

Title: Expectation-Maximization Algorithm
Notes: Iterative estimation in latent variable models. E-step computes expected log-likelihood. M-step maximizes. Used in Gaussian mixture models.

Title: Forward Price
Notes: No-arbitrage forward price for asset with continuous dividend yield. Derived from cash-and-carry arbitrage.

Title: Put-Call Parity
Notes: Fundamental relationship between European call and put prices with same strike and maturity. Violation creates arbitrage.

Title: Geometric Brownian Motion
Notes: Stochastic differential equation modeling asset price dynamics. Foundation of modern derivatives pricing. Ensures positive prices.

Title: Black-Scholes PDE
Equation: \frac{\partial V}{\partial t} + rS\frac{\partial V}{\partial S} + \frac{1}{2}\sigma^2 S^2 \frac{\partial^2 V}{\partial S^2} = rV
Notes: Partial differential equation governing European option prices. Derived via Itô's lemma and delta-hedging.

Title: Black-Scholes Call Option Price
Notes: Closed-form solution for European call. d_1 = [ln(S_0/K) + (r - q + σ²/2)T]/(σ√T), d_2 = d_1 - σ√T.

Title: Black-Scholes Put Option Price
Notes: Closed-form solution for European put. Alternatively derivable from put-call parity.

Title: Delta (Option Greek)
Notes: First derivative of option value with respect to underlying price. Hedge ratio for delta-neutral position.

Title: Gamma (Option Greek)
Notes: Second derivative; rate of change of delta. Measures curvature and hedging error from discrete rebalancing.

Title: Theta (Option Greek)
Notes: Time decay of option value. Typically negative for long options. Related to gamma via BS PDE.

Title: Vega (Option Greek)
Notes: Sensitivity to volatility changes. Always positive for long vanilla options. Peaks at-the-money.

Title: Itô's Lemma
Equation: dF = \left(\frac{\partial F}{\partial t} + \mu S \frac{\partial F}{\partial S} + \frac{1}{2}\sigma^2 S^2 \frac{\partial^2 F}{\partial S^2}\right)dt + \sigma S \frac{\partial F}{\partial S} dW_t
Notes: Fundamental result in stochastic calculus; chain rule for Itô processes. Foundation for BS PDE derivation.

Title: Girsanov Theorem
Notes: Enables change between probability measures via drift adjustment. Market price of risk θ = (μ - r)/σ. Foundation for risk-neutral pricing.

Title: Feynman-Kac Formula
Notes: Links PDEs to stochastic expectations. Solution to parabolic PDEs expressible as conditional expectation. Enables Monte Carlo pricing.

Title: Binomial Option Pricing Model
Equation: V_0 = e^{-rT} \sum_{k=0}^n \binom{n}{k} p^k (1-p)^{n-k} \max(S_0 u^k d^{n-k} - K, 0)
Notes: Discrete-time lattice model. Risk-neutral probability p = (e^{rΔt} - d)/(u - d). Converges to Black-Scholes as n→∞.

Title: Vasicek Model
Notes: Mean-reverting Ornstein-Uhlenbeck process for short rate. First equilibrium interest rate model. Closed-form bond pricing.

Title: Cox-Ingersoll-Ross Model
Notes: Mean-reverting square-root diffusion for short rate. Ensures non-negative rates if 2κθ ≥ σ² (Feller condition).

Title: Hull-White Model
Notes: Extended Vasicek with time-dependent mean. Fits current yield curve exactly. Used for Bermudan swaptions.

Title: Heath-Jarrow-Morton Framework
Notes: Models evolution of entire forward rate curve. Drift determined by volatility via no-arbitrage. General term structure framework.

Title: Black's Model (Caplet)
Notes: Market standard for pricing interest rate caplets. d_1 = [ln(L_i/K) + σ²T_i/2]/(σ√T_i), d_2 = d_1 - σ√T_i.

Title: Swaption Pricing (Black's Formula)
Equation: V_{\text{payer}} = P(0,T_0) \cdot A(T_0,T_n) [S_{0,n}(0) N(d_1) - K N(d_2)]
Notes: Payer swaption: option to enter swap at future time T_0 paying fixed K. A = swap annuity. Used for callable bonds.

Title: Credit Default Swap Pricing
Equation: V_{CDS} = \sum_{i=1}^n P(0,T_i) Q(T_i) (1 - R) - s \sum_{i=1}^n \tau_i P(0,T_i) [1 - Q(T_i)]
Notes: Value to protection buyer. First term = protection leg, second term = premium leg. At par, spread s chosen so V_CDS = 0.

Title: Merton's Structural Model
Notes: Treats equity as call option on firm value V with strike equal to debt D. Firm defaults if V_T < D.

Title: Heston Stochastic Volatility Model
Equation: dS_t = \mu S_t dt + \sqrt{v_t} S_t dW_t^S, \quad dv_t = \kappa(\theta - v_t)dt + \xi \sqrt{v_t} dW_t^v
Notes: Two-factor model with stochastic variance. Correlation ρ between W^S and W^v generates volatility smile.

Title: SABR Model
Notes: Stochastic Alpha Beta Rho for forward rates. β = CEV exponent. Industry standard for rates and FX.

Title: Local Volatility (Dupire)
Equation: \sigma_{local}^2(K,T) = \frac{\frac{\partial C}{\partial T} + (r-q)K\frac{\partial C}{\partial K} + qC}{\frac{1}{2}K^2\frac{\partial^2 C}{\partial K^2}}
Notes: Dupire's formula for local volatility implied by market option prices. Unique diffusion that fits implied volatility surface.

Title: Value at Risk (Parametric)
Notes: Maximum expected loss over time horizon Δt at confidence level α. Basel regulatory capital based on 10-day 99% VaR.

Title: Expected Shortfall (CVaR)
Notes: Conditional VaR: expected loss given loss exceeds VaR threshold. Coherent risk measure (satisfies subadditivity). Basel III uses ES.
